para: Refine is a that chops its target elements and their neighbors into smaller pieces. This adds more degrees of freedom to the &skel;, which allows it to adapt better to the µ. Refinement by itself is rarely sufficient to create an acceptable &skel; -- it must be combined with other modifiers that move nodes, such as or .

The steps involved in refining a &skel; are:
Find the element edges (&sgmts;) that need to be refined. These are specified by the targets parameter, whose value is a object. Different kinds of objects pick segments in different ways, for example, by choosing all edges of heterogeneous elements or the long edges of skinny elements. See for the details.
shows a &skel; that needs to have its heterogeneous elements refined. Setting targets to marks the edges of all elements whose homogeneity is less than 90%, as shown in .
The divider parameter determines how and where the chosen segments will be divided. Segments are marked for division in in half (), in thirds (), or at .
After the segments are marked for division, each element is replaced by a suitable collection of smaller elements, such that each marked segment of the old &skel; turns into a set number of segments of the new &skel;. Exactly how this is done depends on the setting of the rules parameter. (For details, see the description of .) The rules sometimes allow more than one way of subdividing an element. In those cases, the total effective energy of the new elements is computed, and the configuration with the lowest energy is used. The parameter alpha determines the relative contributions of shape and homogeneity to the effective energy, as discussed in .

caution.para: One should not abuse Refinement to the point where elements become too small. shows a part of &skel; that has been refined to the pixel resolution -- many elements along the boundary represent a single pixel. This is not only unphysical (the jagged pixel boundaries are an artifact of the digitization of the micrograph) but can introduce unnecessary numerical anomalies, such as stress concentrations, at corner nodes.

Instead of abusing refinement, it is better to employ other modification strategies. shows the same portion of the &skel; shown in but with different modification tools applied. This &skel; has been refined less, but the elements have been adapted to the µ by using instead of .
Excessive Refinement
A part of a &skel; that has been refined to the pixel resolution.
Appropriate Refinement
Instead of excessive refinement, other tools have been applied.

As seen, refining too much does not necessarily yield an optimal result. One can, however, prevent this over-refinement by adjusting the refinement criterion. Setting it to causes &oof2; to reject any refinement that results in an element whose area is smaller than a specified value.
